name: Time to go through some single player modules!
author: Orion

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Time to head back to single player again!
Looking for challenging modules, or great story. Maybe some up to lvl 40 modules if they are around
Have done Aielund saga I-VI (level 1 to level 36-38) before, great module, but won't replay it, finding it a bit too easy now and I know the story.

On the list to try:
- Mines of Twin Summit (to lvl 40)
- Sands of Fate (level 40)
- Lord of Terror (level 30)
- Aribeth's Redemption to lvl 28 
- Swordflight lvl 24-26 I think with future modules pending
- Eye of the Beholder (not sure what lvl)

If there are any other suggestions feel free to suggest!

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Have you tried Infinite Dungeons yet?

If not, it is pretty interesting!  And has levelling to 40.

posts.author: Aquarius 233
posts.content:
Swordflight should bring you to lv 32 or 33, considering the latest episode (4th) released.

Some suggestions from my side:
  • Return to Ravenloft and sequel --> from lv 1 to lv 17 or 18, great Ravenloft atmosphere;
  • A hunt through the dark --> this modules makes you play as a drow, and takes you to early epics (22-24 range, don't recall). Great story, you can decide you behave evilly or not (and ending is different);
  • Tales of Arterra --> this is a two-parts module (play both the Awakening and the Lost), many henchmen, great story, takes you to epics. This is an highly acclaimed module;
  • Caereena --> lv from 20 to 30, I have not played it but there are many positive reviews: it's on my "to play" list;
  • Sapphire star --> takes from lv 1 to lv 10, but it is tough and recommended;
  • Army of one --> very fun module, I really liked it. Many henchmen, from lv 20 to 25, the ending battle is epic;
  • Bastard of Kosigan --> this is an english translation of a french author's module; story is beautifully developed, although ending is not complete. Takes to early epics, and I greatly recommend it. Just don't play it with textures improvements in your override or patch override, otherwise there will be crashes. Second part has some issues related to module uploading, but if you don't use overrides other than GUI improvements it wll give you fewer issues. this is the link to latest part.
    • As the first english part is the real second part in french (as the first one has not been translated), recommended starting level should be around 8; some battles are tough.
  • Ultima IV --> remake of a pc game. I don't know how much is faithful to the older one, but I had fun playing it, from lv 1 to 24-25. Different mechanics from general modules, medieval language, very particular.
The only module I have not played from this list is Caereena, but will do it someday.

Hope that this can help!

Edit: forgot to add Udasu's the accursed tower : takes you from lv 1 to lv 11, but story is well explained, there are dialogues with henchmen and it has a P 'n p feel. Seems that there are other recommended Udasu's modules (like lankhmar nights), you may want to give them a look; they are in my "to play" list, as I really liked the accursed tower.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Thank you Web and especially Aquarius! Wow wow so much stuff to get through. 
I did purchase the Infinite Dungeons DLC, I tried a bit of it, its a little story light but I can see how the combat can be appealing, I might put that at the end somewhere, I do like a nice tale!

posts.author: Aquarius 233
posts.content:
Glad that this has helped a bit!

Just forgot others already downloaded and in my "to play" list:
  • challenge of the overfiend --> short but (seooms from reviews) tough module for early epic characters;
  • Age of mortals --> based on Dragonlance, it seems an offline version of a server (don't know if it is still active, though), and gets to lv 40. There seems to be an updated version here.
  • Deja vu --> for clerics, takes you from lv 1 to 16;
  • siege of the heavens --> this seems a very tough one, basically this is a "test" for lv 40 pc. bosses have different features.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
A few more thoughts for you:

Saleron's Gambit
Endless Nights
Shadowlords, Dreamcatcher & Demon (the Adam Miller campaign)
Tournament of Champions
Tyrants of the Moonsea

All of these feature in our Modules forum - as does the Caereena module Aquarius mentions, and was brought to us by Dallo, one of its authors.

Iirc Honor Among Thieves has also received positive feedback, as has Snowhunt (Lilura certainly rates that one) and if you fancy playing evil following HotU, there's also The Gods Themselves (afraid I don't have the links, sorry).

Cheers

posts.content: Thanks as well Stag!  a list of 28 modules! all either free to play or low cost DLC. Should get some more suggestions from more ECB members, find all the links then sticky this thread for new comers to read! Maybe we can get up to 50! That will keep all comers busy for a long time! Unless this thread has been done before! The ECB guild members single player module list!

posts.author: gkorjax

A Dance with Rogues is one of my favorites. It has a very gritty story. Not for those who want to avoid ...difficult subjects. Written by a woman (listed as such). Very different.
It has a part 2.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Just some brief comments on that, don't have nearly enough time to make a full analysis/explanation, but I've played a lot from these modules & I like them challenging too...

Dance with Rogues: Good (especially for its time) but has lots of virtual sex, so don't have kids around. Lot's of rogue-like quests.
The Beholder modules: Good graphics (push this ancient engine to its limits) but the story is very basic & the final fight super-tough. Not recommended.
MTS: Good for a quick weekend play, easy to finish, lots of boss-monsters. Lots of fighting. Very basic scripts, once you have the right immunities, you just watch the show.
Sands of Fate: Epic Egypt, lots of monsters, basic story, a ton of items & some special enemies that ignore immunities. Super-high magic, class-abilities become irrelevant, some old-school Gygaxian traps in there, lots of nostalgia. Eh, play it, although its nothing special.
Aribeth: I don't like the writing, contrary to what most people say, she is very spoiled, a single mistake & she is bye-bye, forcing a reload. Not recommended.
Lord of Terror: Make sure you install the optional music pack too. Play a Paladin. Have your volume turned-up. Enjoy the fights & the awe-inspiring voice of Michael Gough.
Saleron's Gambit: Very good. The story is top-notch. Levels are low but everything that you do feels important. Highly recommended.
Tournament of Champions: Make a Pale-warrior or you are going to regret it... Good for an evening's play & some instant high-level action. Enter the module & customize the gear & feats of your opponents to create any ECB builds that you like & then go & playtest them.
The Arena of Champions: The "advanced" version of the previous one. Actual story-line, lots of options for the fights, place bets & have two teams of epic warriors fight. It comes with an actual builds-manual. Nothing as good as actual ECB builds but the effort alone is worth it. Tons of scripting, & lots of fun. Avoid getting Dev Crit in that for the optimal challenge, otherwise, it gets too easy. Also, avoid taking your weapons to the max (+20), for the same reason. This was the module that Kail back in time tested the Jormungandr & actually beat the first two fights (without gear).
Adam Miller campaign: Good, old-time classic. Goes up to 18th-level. Worth it even today, I think.
Almraiven & Shadewood: Yeah, the story is good. Yes, the magic feels very realistic. Yes, the tilesets are fine. Is that good enough? Not for me, it is slow & with little action. In general, I do not like these hyper-realistic d&d games. Strangely, although Saleron's Gambit is also "realistic" it has lots more action & feels totally fine. I would stick with Saleron's for this.
Bastard of Kosigan: Can't remember much but I remember it is good. It is actually middle-ages Europe. Three parts module.
A Hunt through the Dark: Play a Drow, seven-part series, some good fights but old design that shows its age. Average.
Honor amongst Thieves: A rogue-mainly module. Not enough of them around. Old but classic. Goes up to medium levels. I would play it again.
Siege of Heavens: It is just some instant level-forty action against set encounters but they are custom & have their own unique properties. Good scripting but not exactly ECB testing material. I would stick with the Tournament & Arena of Champions for testing ECB builds.

There are some other good modules/series of modules, like the Blackguard series (up to 24th-level). Keep an eye on them, too. Back in the day, I would also playtest entire PW's alone or with some friends but unless they have some really good scripting I would stick to modules. Something else to keep in mind. You would want to install Tony's AI before you play any single--player module (except perhaps, Swordflight), otherwise, with your current experience they would be easy for you. Heck, they would be easy even with Tony's AI but its better than nothing. Yes, Tony's AI has its downsides, yes it's unnatural for cows to try & hide from sight & yes, it will make every enemy mage only ever use Bigby's & Isaac's, etc. But it's far better from the standard AI man, I can't stand it as-is, especially for the henchmen.

That's all for now, hope it was somewhat useful.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Thanks Valerfor this is fabulous review of a large number of modules from the perspective of an experienced player. 
Thanks for sharing your experience.

Addit: I noted @demoix one of the guild members, updated TonyK's AI early this year, for NWN2.
(https://neverwintervault.org/project/nw ... nsperre-ai)

Any plans for a NWN version? :) With EE there might be a lot of interest, 
if there are lots of players playing against the AI (such as WoG, for example), they can identify weaknesses and the AI can get improved as a result
One example being using summons to bait out the enemy mage's most powerful spells, perhaps spells such as Time Stop / Mord's and Bigby's 6-7-9 can be saved for use against players

Addit 2: found Jasperre's AI for NWN 1 (https://neverwintervault.org/project/nw ... rres-ai-13) updated only a month ago

Also found a tutorial on how to write one's own combat AI scripts :)
(https://neverwintervault.org/article/tu ... h-ai-depth)
Not sure I'm quite ready to do that kind of thing yet.

How very very interesting!

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Jasperre's AI is one I used for my PW.

It is pretty good imo.

posts.author: Asturonethoriusaline
posts.content:
MY MOD LIST

I had a problem with my phone and NWN. Wont go into story details, but I lost all my Mods, Saves, NWN stuff.

Silver Lining is got NWN reinstalled and the greyed out PW's working again, altho still lost saves.

So here is MY MOD LIST:

1. Raines WOG:

I still cant play the PW version. But the offline single player version of the Mod version of the PW is the best.

It Mirrors the online PW, except its OFFLINE, and you have to solo it.

2. Aielund, havent played it, but will soon, got it installed working ready to play.

3. Lord of Terror.

4. Caereena

5. Diablo the complete Remake

6. Eye of the Beholder

7. Bard's Tale, Tales of the Unknown.

8. Pools of Radiance Attack on Ruins of Myth Drannor

9. Wizardry Proving Grounds of a Mad Wizard

10. Pool of Radiance, the remake of the gold box game, the saving of the city of New Phlan, SOU version(Newer, better Version, then the older version.

11. Eye of the Beholder 2 Darkmoon(Wish Eye of the Beholder 3, Assault on Myth Drannor was available, to complete the Eye of the Beholder Trilogy)

I'm sure there are others I should consider getting, but these are the ones I have installed, playing.

posts.author: Aquarius 233
posts.content:
I am curious about The Bard's tale and Pool of Radiance; which is the ending level of the pc?
Don't know when, but I'll take them for a spin!

posts.author: Asturonethoriusaline
posts.content:
Aquarius 233 wrote: ↑
Aug 12, 2020
I am curious about The Bard's tale and Pool of Radiance; which is the ending level of the pc?
Don't know when, but I'll take them for a spin!
Bard's Tale supposedly is supposed to end about 25th to 37th level depending on how much you grind, killing respawns, etc.

There are 6 extremely HUGE ultimate Dungeons, with each dungeon having 2,3,4 levels+ per dungeon, with each level being big.

Culminates in a battle against a Epic Archmage named Mangar

Pool Of Radiance(Tyranthraxus(Save New Phlan):

You want the SOU version.

Its for levels 1 to 10.

Pools of Radiance, Attack on Ruins of Myth Drannor(Fight against Cult of the Dragon, Battle a Draco Lich, Spellcaster Boss at End)

4,5,6 part series, takes from minimum level 6 to minimum level 16.
